origin:
THREAD

I just spoke with @AOC and honestly, it's rare that I feel this inspired by a conversation.

The main takeaway was this: we are not going to be able to solve these generations-long discussions in one tweet or one call. 

What we can do is model how to talk about them.
replies:
We live in a world that sees these discussions as zero-sum. Where we win or lose. Where openness to engagement is a danger, not an opportunity.

But when we're talking about things as difficult as anti-Semitism, Islamophobia, and Israel/Palestine, engagement is the only answer.

Speaking to @AOC was beautiful because she was honest about her desire to keep listening, but also to keep giving voice to the marginalized. 

We simply can't just follow easy talking-points to end these debates. We have to give all a voice.

There is no way but the hard way. The one where we talk about the things that divide us. Where we hear people that make us deeply uncomfortable, maybe even fearful.

But as long as we are working in good faith towards a common vision, we can accomplish this task.

But the other way, the one of silencing, of quietness, of marginalizing those we have deep divisions with (despite our shared visions), is the one where no one wins. Zero-sum equals zero justice.

That's why I'm thankful for the discussion with AOC and hope for more.

There are not many leaders willing to take on these hard discussions. Or to model change. Or to actually change how we approach things as opposed to digging into how others engage.

Thank you, @AOC, for being one one of the leaders who is willing to model true change.

/Thread

PS (1/2) - Yes, we spoke about Corbyn. That was the first half of the conversation. I laid out his various anti-Semitic acts and I also pointed out how the Jewish community in Britain has engaged with this topic.

I believe she heard my concerns and took them seriously.

But the reason I highlighted the above is that IMO the rest of the discussion was important: how do we create a space to discuss these issues?

People who were expecting this discussion to create a quick resolution to this issue are part of why this discussion is problematic. 2/2
For anyone unaware, this is the context of the discussion and how it occurred: https://twitter.com/AOC/status/1092227273682550784¬†‚Ä¶
Thanks for taking the time. I‚Äôm thankful we could share a compassionate and productive conversation that hopefully lays the groundwork for future dialogue.

It was my honor. And I love your phrasing: this is not about a quick, easy resolution, but a difficult process. 

Honored to be part of it in any way, and so excited to see where all this, and all your work in general, goes.
